verses.text: Listen to me, you who pursue righteousness, you who seek the LORD. Look to the rock from which you were cut, and to the quarry from which you were dug.
verses.comment: The 'rock' refers to the ancestry of Abraham (v.2) and symbolizes the origin of faith. The theme anticipates Christ as the true Rock (1 Cor. 10:4), showing a connection between the people's past and their hope for redemption.

verses.text: Look to Abraham your father, and to Sarah who gave birth to you; for he was but one when I called him, and I blessed him and made him many.
verses.comment: Recalling Abraham highlights that God's power brings life from barrenness. This anticipates spiritual descendants through faith in Christ (Gal. 3:7), a theme expanded in the New Testament.

verses.text: For the LORD will comfort Zion; he will comfort all her ruins. He will make her wilderness like Eden, her desert like the garden of the LORD. Joy and gladness will be found in her, thanksgiving and the sound of singing.
verses.comment: The restoration of Zion is described with language reminiscent of Eden, suggesting not just physical return but spiritual renewal. The Church fulfills this renewal in Christ, returning humanity to fellowship with God.

verses.text: Pay attention to me, my people, and give ear to me, my nation; for a law will go forth from me, and I will establish my justice as a light for the peoples.
verses.comment: Foretells a new law and justice given not only to Israel but to all nations. This looks forward to the law of Christ spread throughout the world.

verses.text: My righteousness is near, my salvation has gone out, and my arms will judge the peoples; the coastlands wait for me, and for my arm they hope.
verses.comment: The 'arm' of the LORD is a symbol of divine power and later is fully revealed in Jesus (Isa. 53:1). The invitation to the 'coastlands' hints at the inclusion of the Gentiles.

verses.text: Lift up your eyes to the heavens, and look at the earth beneath; for the heavens will vanish like smoke, and the earth will wear out like a garment, and those who dwell in it will die in the same way. But my salvation will be forever, and my righteousness will never end.
verses.comment: Contrast between the temporary nature of creation and the eternal nature of God's salvation and righteousness. Jesus echoes these words in the Gospels about the eternity of his words.

verses.text: Listen to me, you who know righteousness, the people in whose heart is my law; do not fear the reproach of men, nor be dismayed at their insults.
verses.comment: Encourages the righteous to hold fast, paralleling Jesus' beatitudes about persecution for righteousness' sake.

verses.text: For the moth will eat them up like a garment, and the worm will eat them like wool; but my righteousness will be forever, and my salvation to all generations.
verses.comment: Calls attention to the impermanence of human glory versus the enduring nature of God's salvation, echoing teaching about heavenly treasure.

verses.text: Awake, awake, put on strength, O arm of the LORD! Awake, as in days of old, the generations of long ago. Was it not you who cut Rahab in pieces, who pierced the sea monster?
verses.comment: Rahab here refers symbolically to Egypt. This is an appeal for God's mighty deliverance like the Exodus, prefiguring the ultimate deliverance brought by Christ.

verses.text: Was it not you who dried up the sea, the waters of the great deep, who made the depths of the sea a pathway for the redeemed to cross over?
verses.comment: References the Exodus, a foreshadowing of salvation through water, which is continued in New Testament sacramental imagery.

verses.text: So the ransomed of the LORD will return and come to Zion with singing. Everlasting joy will be upon their heads; they will obtain gladness and joy, and sorrow and sighing will flee away.
verses.comment: Describes the homecoming of the redeemed. It points to the ultimate gathering of God's people, fulfilled spiritually in the heavenly Jerusalem.

verses.text: I, I am he who comforts you. Who are you that you are afraid of man who dies, and of the son of man who is made like grass,
verses.comment: God himself is the comforter. This theme is taken up in the New Testament with the Holy Spirit called the 'Comforter' (John 14:16).

verses.text: and have forgotten the LORD, your Maker, who stretched out the heavens and laid the foundations of the earth, and you live in constant fear all day because of the fury of the oppressor, as he aims to destroy? But where is the fury of the oppressor?
verses.comment: Reminds God's people of His creative power. Calls them to trust in Him, over earthly powers.

verses.text: He who is bowed down will soon be released; he will not die and go down to the pit, nor will he lack bread.
verses.comment: Promises liberation for those oppressed. Spiritually, points to deliverance from sin and death, nourished by the bread from heaven.

verses.text: For I am the LORD your God, who stirs up the sea so that its waves roar—the LORD of hosts is his name.
verses.comment: Reiterates God's sovereign power. The LORD of hosts is associated throughout the prophets with universal authority.

verses.text: And I have put my words in your mouth and covered you with the shadow of my hand, to establish the heavens, to lay the foundations of the earth, and to say to Zion, 'You are my people.'
verses.comment: This relates to the prophetic commission, but also to the Word made flesh, Jesus, who is the ultimate fulfillment of God’s word and covenant people.

verses.text: Wake yourself, wake yourself, stand up, O Jerusalem, you who have drunk from the hand of the LORD the cup of his wrath, you who have drunk to the dregs the bowl, the cup of staggering.
verses.comment: The ‘cup’ of God's wrath is a frequent image for judgment, which Jesus refers to in Gethsemane (Luke 22:42), ultimately taking it upon himself for our redemption.

verses.text: There is no one to guide her among all the children she has borne; there is no one to take her by the hand among all the sons she has raised.
verses.comment: Jerusalem's abandonment is total, a result of judgment, but sets up the need for a Messiah who alone can shepherd and restore God's people.

verses.text: These two things have happened to you—who will console you?—devastation and destruction, famine and sword; how shall I comfort you?
verses.comment: Judgment has come. Comfort and restoration can only come from God when his people turn back to him, foreshadowing the comfort brought through the Messiah.

verses.text: Your sons have fainted; they lie at the head of every street like an antelope caught in a net; they are full of the LORD's wrath, the rebuke of your God.
verses.comment: Describes the total weakness of the people under judgment, needing divine intervention to be restored.

verses.text: Therefore hear this, you afflicted one, who is drunk, but not with wine:
verses.comment: The description of drunkenness from wrath—not wine—signals deep spiritual need, reminding us of the need for inner transformation rather than just outward reform.

verses.text: Thus says your Lord, the LORD your God who pleads the cause of his people: 'Behold, I have taken from your hand the cup of staggering; the bowl, the cup of my wrath, you shall drink no more.'
verses.comment: God himself promises to remove judgment. The language of a ‘cup’ here is fulfilled when Christ drinks the cup of wrath for us, inaugurating a new and everlasting covenant.

verses.text: I will put it into the hand of those who afflict you, who have said to you, 'Bow down, that we may walk over you'; and you have made your back like the ground and like the street for them to pass over.
verses.comment: Reversal of fortunes: oppressors now bear the cup of judgment. This completes the cycle of restoration for God's people and points to Christ’s victory over evil.
